I made the trip to Washington and back in once piece. It was a long journey, and I kept a journal of those days on the road. I will type this journal up and post it on here shortly. So I wont talk about the trip this post. Meanwhile back at home things are going alright. I have gotten my credit card paid off, even finished a few models on the side. I started redesigning my website as some of you can tell, in the end it should look much like this page does now. Note, you should now have the option to leave comments to each of my posts, assuming this whole thing works. If not, oh well. :P I am getting ready to move and thinking about doors that have opened to me in the past month. I now have 3 options where to live when I move, I haven't decided on one yet though. You might ask, why am I being lazy about it? Why haven't I decided yet? Well there is a 4th option, one which I haven't mentioned to many people. I have been offered a job in Denver, doing webpage design for a professional company out there. In fact its a far better paying job than what I have here (about 40k a year), I would have to interview for it, and certainly there is no 100% guarantee that I will get the job. If I did, it would be an opportunity to get out of the state for a while and make a decient living. The problem however is if I am sure I want to leave or not, fear on my part. I know Katie lives in Denver and she is not the reason I would move, this is just an oddly timed coincidence. However I can't claim that I don't think about living closer to her like this, because it crosses my mind constantly. Mostly, I wonder what would happen if I lived that close, not to me, but to her. I think my fears stem from the possibility of upsetting her by moving there potentially or possibly in someway making things difficult for her by me being nearby. Most of you know I worry about things to much, and I am nutorious for overthinking things in life around me. For all intents and purposes things very well may just be fine and I might get to see her from time to time. But then, there is the second problem.. What happens to everyone here that I'd leave behind? Would everyone be alright? How would Sarah, Jeni, Keven, Johnny and others react to my leave? Part of me knows deep down inside that I need to leave for a while, to see the world, new people and places. I've lived here so long its engrained in my heart, all of the things here, things I wish I could take with me. Ultimatly it comes down to what is going to be best for me, and right now I can't decide, I am close to leaning either way. So I am asking those of you who read this, what should I do? Assuming the comments bit works, leave me a comment and give me your advice.

This is a public service announcement: I love it when I get calls to the office. But the person calling doesn't leave a number for me to call back OR even a message for that matter. So far this week I've recieved calls from: "Hope" and "Nika" Now.. Hope would be interesting, could it be my long lost friend Hope?? She has my cell # though... and who is "Nika"? In both cases these people said they wo uld call back, guess what! THEY NEVER DID!!! ARGH!!!!!!! /end public service announcement In other news, I have been dreaming again. Yes dreams as strange as always.. Nothing describes the feeling of dreaming about someone that you haven't talked to in a while. Are they ok? Am I ok? Have I lost my marbles? Is it my sub-concious? Or is my empathy trying to tell me something? Normally a dream or two isn't important.. But I am talking about sheer volume here.. I normally don't remember dreams, but I've woken up remembering them for 3 weeks now. They are all "related" in some way, and none of them make any logical sense, like the pieces of 4 similar puzzles mixed into the same box. There's a train down at the station, it's come to carry my bones away. Two engines on, twenty-one coaches long, end to end, twenty-one coaches bend. The watchman's out kicking the bums about.

As a testiment to the quality work I bumble through everyday. We had a customer concerned about a ticket order he had placed. As it turns out his order said he was going to get charged something like 25,023,324.00 I took the time to investigate how on earth this happened. Everything in the database looked fine, one ticket at $190. Nothing major there. The email it sent me read fine, so I wondered how only he would get a message saying that? On a whim I did some digging and noticed something strange in the code. What happened was my changing the form each event so I dont have to re-write the whole thing. Well last event they had me add this field for a second special pre-event. This time I needed to add a field for "Registering Mentor", so I reused the old pre-event field in the database and form keeping the same input name used previously. Well I had forgotten that the pre-event ticket price was hardcoded into the order page. In addition a persons "Registering Mentor" is an IBO number, usually around 7 digits long. So when the form was submitted, some wild math took over. Something like this: Total = (Ticket Price * Number Of Tickets) + (Registering Mentor * 39.00) See what happens when I rush to do code when I am half asleep? Thankfully however, no one was harmed or over charged. The system still does credit card payment the old fashioned way. Enough of my programming foibles. Over the weekend I got to play City of Heroes, which I must say is a pretty entertaining game. Corey and Lori got their own copies and when they are at work they are going to let me play on Corey's account until I get my own copy. Daniel has been busy getting ready to move. Most of his stuff is packed and ready to go. Most of the weekend was slow, Corey and I went nuts driving around Sac on Friday night. Saturday I pretty much sat at the computer staring off into space until I re-installed windows. Sunday I played Battlefield 1942 for about 5 hours straight, managed to get something to eat and then spaced out staring at the wall for about 3 hours. Eventually Kassandra (Lori's bestfriend and an old High School friend of mine) stopped by while doing her paper route and I snapped out of it. We started talking about music, and she asked me if I had some songs, which of course I did, because frankly I have everything. One of which I thought was interesting, the song "God Only Knows" by the Beach Boys (on of my favorite songs). So I played it for her, and told her about how I can sing it, so before she left I sang two songs for her "Surfer Girl" and "God Only Knows". Normally I don't sing for people, I know of about 4 people that have heard me sing. Kassandra told me that I have a beautiful voice and that I made her cry, quite flattering. :) That made my night, I never thought I could make anyone cry from my singing. Maybe I need to sing for people more often.

Well the good news is.. apparently the Police are leaving me alone now. Thank god! I wasn't sure I could live with that stress anymore, it was driving me nuts. I have also managed to borrow enough money to get my car payments caught up. So I will atleast still have my car. :) I even managed to figure out what was wrong with my computer at home. It was down most of the night lastnight but when I get home I should get it fixed back up. I devoted a good portion of my day yesterday to working on my website. It is starting to look more appealing, even though half of the links don't work. I decided to stick with the sort of Victorian Era book appearance, I think its a nice change from the black, white and purple I was using before. Why oh Why I used those nasty colors I will never know.. Tonight, the "gang" and I are having a Farscape marathon, WOO HOO! Actually I don't know how it will go, I never watched much Farscape. As for everything else, I am SO upset at two people that will go unnamed (they know who they are). At this point I hope I never talk to them again, what they have done is uncalled for and downright rude. I honestly could careless anymore. And no, one of these people isn't Katie.

This is my 60th post to my journal.. Doesn't seem like a lot but when I started this I was a year younger and the world was different. In some ways things are the same, in others they have changed dramaticly. But today is my birthday and I am now a whopping 24! What did today hold for me? Well Jessica told me never to contact her again and as far as she is concered I never existed. All because she took offense to my journal post about nicknames. Jeni wrote me a birthday email to tell me that I am a horrible friend and that I apparently don't care about anyone other than myself when they are in need. In the end giving me a nice "Happy Birthday" ending the email. Katie has forgotten about my birthday for the first time ever, though I can't blame her, she's pretty busy the best I can figure. The police think I am a criminal and there is no way that I can see to prove my innocence.. For some reason APD works on the guilty until proven innocent system until they determine otherwise. So as I sat this evening looking at the evening sun setting, I watched the swirled sherbert sky and clouds and thought. This could very well be the worst birthday I've ever had, and that is saying a lot. I've wanted to do nothing but sit at home all day, cry and be alone. Tonight I burn a candle to a year gone by, and I look back at everything leading to this day. The light that glows reminds me that no one has forgotten me this day, that I am in the hearts of many and I mean the world to them even though they can't tell me themselves. I remind myself, that I am loved. Because of this, I remember who I am and where I am going. Though you aren't here this day. I feel you in my heart. The love you give. I cherish my life. To love and be loved. A gift that can't be taken away. Dream of me this night. As I will dream of you.

About two months ago, someone stole a laptop from a person that shares space in my Auburn office. As it turns out it was my friend Mary Helen at Parallax whom it was stolen from. Immediatly there after I recieved a call from the police since I had gone to the office that night to drop something off and check on my servers. More on this in a bit This isn't the first time I've had dealings with the police. Last year around October or so I was called by the Sheriff reguarding a coworker who had left her new husband and was out running around with some guy. The Sheriff explained that she came home and told her husband that she had been raped. He took her to the police station where she confessed that she wasn't really raped but had cheated on her husband, it was a mistake and she didn't want him to find out. The police filed a report anyway and asked her who she had slept with "just in case". Among those people she named me off. So the officer was calling to confirm this with me, after the inital shock of the words "sheriff's office, rape and questions" I was sort of freaked. However I never had any sort of relationship with this person in that manner. From time to time she would come visit me at the appt and vent about her husband who she felt treated her bad. I explained this to the deputy and everything got squared away. Needless to say, calls from the police scare me. Back to the matter at hand. After the theft of the laptop I got a call from APD to ask some questions about if I had seen anyone since I was the last one out of the building. I did my best to describe what I remembered and explained why I was there. I also explained why I had turned the alarm off and a minute later turned it back on. The reason? Because there was another guy working when I came in, when he left he didn't realise I was there and turned the alarm on while I was in the building. In order to leave I had to turn the alarm off and then back on again. The officer understood and that was the last I heard of it. Fast forward to today. I had recieved a call from a different officer yesterday asking if I could come in for some questions. I said sure since I wanted to see the thief caught as much as they did. Mary Helen lost a lot of work that was on her laptop and I felt bad for her. I show up around 11am this morning to answer questions and I am lead to an interogation room and the questioning begins. However, this isn't the same type of questioning as before. 2 months ago I wasn't a suspect and Mary Helen vouched for me to the officers before that she knows me and knows I didn't take it since I do work for her from time to time and such. Today however, I was the prime suspect. The questioning wasn't so much questioning as it was trying to get me to confess. They threw all sorts of things at me, like supposedly having me on tape in the act to talking to my coworkers who had said when I am around things tend to "vanish". I explained my side and told them everything I knew, everything I saw and tried to prove that it couldn't have been me. In fact I mentioned that I had been chatting to people online from my office when I was there so I had a record of what I was doing the whole time I was there (about an hour). The first officer stepped out for a bit and sent in officer #2, a much hardened and too the point guy. He explained that they just wanted the laptop back and asked if I knew what the punishment was for this sort of thing. I said I wasn't sure and he sort of was agast at that, but what the hell would I know? I'm not a criminal.. Again he brought up the tape, and how could it not be me if said tape shows me in the act, etc.. I got upset at this point and told them that their tape was wrong and it must have been someone that looked like me, but it SURE AS HELL was NOT ME. I remember everything I did that night and I didn't even go near that part of the building. I did what I had to do and left. Finally I was given the option to take a lie detector test and of course I said yes. The officer asked me what I thought the test would prove and I said that I didn't do it. So they tried to get the guy they needed to do it but he wont be available until tomorrow, so they let me leave and to come back tomorrow (I had the option the whole time to leave whenever I liked but I felt it would look bad if I didn't answer things to the best of my ability). So all day today I've been very upset, I went and spoke to Mary Helen and she pointed out that whomever took the laptop didn't bother to take the cords effectively making it useless without a way to charge the battery and that if someone tech savy like myself would have taken it, I would have taken the cords. I then talked to my bosses and told them whats going on and if they had some "miracle" evidence somehow that I might not be to work for a while. They made a mention that they don't know what coworkers they talked to but it wasn't anyone that they know of in Foresthill. Which is about 99% of the employees. They also said not to worry they don't have any evidence and there are no cameras, my boss of all people would know this since we have thousands of dollars of equipment there. But my question is why? What sort of questioning was that.. there was no questions just "we know what happened and we know it was you" when in fact it wasn't. It seemed they wanted BADLY for me to confess to the crime going far enough to tell me that they could get a warrant for my arrest TODAY if they wanted to. They seemed to be focusing on me and the other guy that was there who was unlikely to steal anything since he never leaves his office, I don't even know his name. Despite the fact that Mary Helen is near a door which most of the day is unlocked and doesn't close properly, and that she left at 6pm when people come and go from 6pm to 10pm as they please. It could have been ANYONE that just walked into the open door grabbed it and ran off. Instead, they are trying to make it some sort of "inside job" with me as the prime suspect apparently. I knew APD sucked ass, but this is just plain stupid! Everyone knows it wasn't me except the people investigating the damn thing. They must have run out of ideas and thats why its taken them 2 months to decide I did it. Its bullshit and I am mad as hell. So tomorrow I go in for my "test" and if somehow I fail the damn thing I am getting a public defender and I am going to not only prove I am innocent but sue the bastards for this harassment. This is fucked up!

Its funny the people you meet on the bus.. I've heard horror stories, well we've all heard horror stories to be honest. Thankfully on my journey, I was spared the insane or the weirdos. I met some interesting people thats for sure, but no one I would classify as terrible. First up: Texas Guy. The first person I had the pleasure of sitting next to was this quite outspoken man from Texas. But rather than being annoying in a stereotypical Texan fashion he was actually quite an interesting guy. It turns out he hates Texas and is moving to Oregon, so he spent some time bagging on Texas and enjoying the scenery. I was going with him as far as LA so in LA I showed him the Hollywood sign and other sights as we drove past them. All in all he was a pretty cool guy. Also on the trip there was a cool guy going back to Ohio. He was a nice guy and was actually on the trip with me all the way to Denver when he continued and I got off the bus. The funny part is that for the most part he looked like a Neandertal. If you saw this guy on the street you'd expect him to grunt and beat his chest. He was nearly completely covered in hair and even had the facial features, it was odd to say the least. However he was a really cool guy and it turns out he was going home to Ohio to see his family and such. Depite these two cool folk, there was one VERY strange guy that got on the bus in Stockton.. He apparently was from San Diego and decided to just get on the bus and go one day in some sort of "find myself" mission. The problem? It seemed he had been on the bus too long, and went off a couple times with these deep thoughtful hippie like ramblings.. in response to a question.. He would just start to ramble and it made no sense delivering such classy lines as "You've given me what only a woman can give!" in response to someone giving him a cigarette. Oddly enough, with a shortage of seats on the bus he gave up his seat to someone and walked off the bus. We assumed he'd be back on since there were a few seats left. Apparently not.. the bus left without him, thankfully. Also on the bus I met 2 guys from Weimar who were headed to San Diego, they seemed pretty cool but I didnt talk to them much. From LA to Denver there werent many new people. I encountered a couple foreign girls in LA who were waiting for a bus, I over heard them talking. More on these girls later. We did pick up two girls going back to Vegas, one had her little daughter with her that was 9 weeks old. It turns out neither knew the other was from Vegas and wound up sitting next to each other and hit it off. They were right behind me so I could hear everything they said. The "mom" had left her boyfriend and was staying with family in LA, she began to his the boyfriend a lot and was going home. The other girl got in some sort of fight and was kicked out of her grandpa's where she was staying so she was going home. The problem? Well these two girls were about as "ghettofied" as you can get, and proceeded to talk about their thug boyfriends and what gangs they rolled with, etc... As creepy as that was they were quite nice and the "mom" spied me sketching the mountains and I talked to them both a little. When we reached Vegas about half the bus got off and while I was standing around, I encountered the Foreign girls again who had taken the later bus. This time there were 6 of them. I happened to wind up talking to them and learned they were from Poland. They had never met each other before and were sort of on a "mission". Which to me seemed very sketchy. This mission was for the 6 of them to move to Vegas, find jobs and stay for 3 months, then return. I didn't know what to think, I could see possibly doing something like that for school or what not, but anywhere but Vegas. I felt sorry for the girls who were just the sweetest people I met the whole trip and I wished I could have stayed longer. There were plenty of seedy characters out on the street that were eyeing them like wolves after a calf. We didn't pick up any from Vegas until about Grand Junction. There we picked up a mom and son, the son was about 12 years old. One of the skinniest kids I've ever seen (YES SKINNIER THAN ME!). He and his mom lived in Denver and he was pointing things out to me on the trip. He was a nice kid and I watched him play gameboy a lot. In Denver I didn't really meet anyone because I didn't have time to socialize. On the return trip I only met two people. One was a guy that seemed to look like an escaped convict. I would have moved my seat if there was room but I wound up setting by him. He was silent most of the trip until about 3 hours into the trip when he said something at a stop. As it turned out he was going home to Salt Lake City and had been on the bus since Tampa after seeing his mom and gay brother. It had been 24 years since he saw his mom and wanted to restore the family bonds again. The problem was the brother was in the way, caused problems and genuinely pissed off this guy. He said to hell with it and went home, he figured it was better this way since he'd been without them for so long, it wasn't worth the trouble now. Pretty sad if you ask me. The other person was this little Asian girl, sweet as can be and took an interest to the previous guys tattoos (his arms were covered). She was very nice and got off the bus in Salt Lake City too. From then on, the bus was pretty empty and I spent most of the time asleep. There was a mom and daughter (daughter was about 3 or 4) and they were pretty nice, the daughter was pretty funny and went to sleep pretty early on.. She bounced from seat to seat enough until she fell asleep I guess. The mom didn't say a whole lot, when she did she sort of sounded like Katie's mom which was strange she too went to sleep after a while. From the Utah stateline to Reno the bus was quiet atleast the few moments I was awake anyway. ;) All in all, I met a lot of nice people and one day if I take the bus again hopefully the trend will continue.

I'm back! After many hours of bus riding, I made it back from Denver last night. I really like Denver, it is one cool town and even though I was walking everywhere, thankfully I never had to walk more than a mile to get where I needed to be. I found it interesting that nearly everything was just right downtown. The Interview went well (I think) and I should find out about the job in a few days. Keep your fingers crossed! I learned a few things on this trip. The major bus stop in LA sucks, its in the most ghetto place I think I've ever been to. Las Vegas sucks too.. I mean 90 degrees at 11pm?? No thanks.. Utah is pretty much still just "Utah". Colorado is very colorful, and I enjoyed the scenery a lot! On the trip in, we went through Grand Junction and along Tennesee Pass, there are some cool towns up there, I even passed places like Vail and what not. We reached Frisco which is wayyy up in the mountains, along the old Boreas Pass line of the Denver South Park and Pacific. It was cold sort of rainy but it was pretty up there. The bus then went up the highway more and we kept gaining altitute working up to around 10,000 level before going through Eisenhour tunnel. I had forgotten the tunnel was there and when we exited the tunnel I was shocked to see where we were.. Silver Plume! Thats right, this trip I got to see in person for the very first time the Georgetown Loop Railroad. Its a neat little operation, and I hope next time I am out there I will get to ride the railroad and spend more time exploring that area. From there we shot down the highway to Denver and I got dropped off at the Union Station in Denver which is a pretty cool building. On the trip back, we took the same route out of town, but rather than going through Silver Plume and the tunnel again we got on to I-40 and headed to Winter Park. This highway alone is one of the most amazing roads I have ever been on! The road wound up the mountain side like stairs until we reached the top of Berthoud Pass, nearly 12,000 feet. The view was beautiful! If I move to Denver that trip will be one I take from time to time when I need to get away. I only wished I had a camera! The rest of the trip wasn't very exciting, mostly because it was dark and until we reached the Salt Lake City area I couldn't see much. It had been 5 years since I was in SLC and it was still like I remember it weather wise. There were some new buildings and a very nice transit system, I was impressed. The rest of the trip was Desert and I remember that part very well from my previous trips out that way. I reached Reno around 4:30pm and Corey and Lori met me to pick me up, when I got home, I sat down, had something to eat and just relaxed. It was certainly an amazing journey, and even if I don't get the job, I am happy because I got away for a while, out on my own just exploring the world. I want to say thanks to the people that helped me on this: Lynn: She was a HUGE help in getting me a hotel room in Denver. I couldn't have made this trip without her. On top of this, when I "didn't want" to go, she kicked my ass and told me to stop being stupid and go. Corey and Lori: They picked me up from Reno with little notice. Originally Lynn had planned to pick me up but some things came up and she wasn't able to make it. In addition to picking me up with so little notice they were both late to work and I felt bad for making them late, but I really appreciate what they did. I will talk more about the people on the bus tomorrow, I met some interesting characters on the trip, and thankfully no real weirdos. :D

This is it.. An hour to go.. I have nearly 3 days of bus ride ahead of me, and I am nervous, and scared. But this trip was my choosing, its a great gamble and one I fought and decided upon mentally to do. Things may wind up being great, they might wind up terrible. Either way, its an adventure. Even though some things had to be changed last minute, things are looking up. I take with me the well wishes of everyone here at home, and those abroad. Farewell my friends, I shall return to you all soon. I will have my cell phone with me and I will try to call everyone I can when I get settled into my hotel. IF for some reason you don't hear from me by Tuesday night, call my cell OR contact the Continental Hotel in Denver and make sure I have checked in. I'll talk to you all soon. Wish me luck

I leave tomorrow at 4:00 for Denver. Currently the plan looks like I will arrive in Denver around 11pm on Tuesday. I will stay the night, go to my interview at 10:00am on Wednesday. After which I'll wander around downtown for a while and get back on the bus at 5pm for the trip home. I should be home around 8am on Friday. All of that travelling for nothing more than a few hours. :P I don't really have anything else to do in Denver, and I don't know anyone there so there is no reason to stay longer at the time being. This weekend has been enjoyable. Corey, Lori and I have been playing a lot of Battlefield 1942. Daniel plays some too but usually winds up shooting us even if we're on the same team. I bought a neat graphic novel yesterday called "Marvels" its essentially the telling of the beginnings of Marvel super heroes from the eyes of a mere mortal. I read the whole thing lastnight, it really is a great story. I wished it was longer than it was. ;)

Today is payday.. this of course means its now time to get my ticket to Denver. For the past 2 days I have been debating going on not. In leau of recient events I've really been in a hard place when it came to planning. It was lastnight however that all of that changed. Lynn, my old drinking buddy came online and was talking to me about my interview. Well I told her that I wasn't going to go because I couldn't afford to get a place to stay in Denver, and so I'd just let this job slip away. But Lynn, always keen to kick my ass when she needs to demanded I stop being stupid and don't do my usual passive dismissal of things when they go wrong. To top it all off, she said she'd pay for a place for me to stay just as long as I went. So the good news is I am without a doubt, going to Denver, and I am going to go to this place and interview my heart out and get this job! I am not planning on staying in Denver longer than I need to this trip. Because I still have rent due at the end of the month I can only miss a few days of work, so I should be gone about 4 days and only 1 day will be actually in Denver. As always I will have my phone with me so if I am needed, it will be easy to get a hold of me. My plan is to leave Monday and be home by late Thursday night. This all sounds good on paper.. but not in my heart. The company I have the interview with is a VERY professional company and does impressive work. Sadly its more impressive than anything I've done graphically.. Backend coldfusion wise its stuff I could do, but I've never been able to stretch my legs graphicly here at foothill.net A result of this, is my page designs being having very dated appearances. Its because of this, I have this feeling like I am not going to get the job and that this is a waste of my time.. But I know that is in my mind and I CAN do this, its just hard to let go of those fears sometimes. Either way, I am going to go and do my best and present things to the best of my ability. I'll see where the road takes me from there.

An article on fark today listed the "50 Greatest Song Parts". Thats right, not the whole song, but the best parts of songs. To see the list go here: urlLink retroCRUSH: Top 50 Song Parts . While its a good list and obviously influenced by personal taste, some of the parts may not appeal to everyone. I decided, that I to would list my favorite 40 song parts. So here we go! 40: The Beatles - "Sun King" As the previous song fades out, the crickets pick up in the beginning of this song. Its really very soothing. However not many people have heard the crickets because they don't listen for them. 39: Ben Folds Five - "One Angry Dwarf.." I have always loved this solo because the chords have a very jazz like tone to them, except they are played angrily, and then at the end he goes into a little run that lends another hint of anger to the song. 38: The Beach Boys - "California Girls" Most people don't catch it right away, but the words "Girls, Girls, Girls, Yeah I Dig Girls" is the perfect touch to the end of the song. 37: Little Guilt Shrine - "Jet, Jackie and J.C." Sure its a song about Jackie Chan, which is alright. But the very end of the song has always seemed to get a chuckle out of me. Out of nowhere comes this seemingly random 60s horror movie ad for "Dr. Jeckl and Sister Hyde". If you haven't heard the song before, let me know. I'll arrange for you to hear it. 36: George Harrison - "Run of the Mill" This is one of George's truely masterful guitar creations. This little piece speaks a lot for the song itself, if you can find a bootleg acoustic version, give it a listen. Otherwise the album version from All Things Must Pass has the same effect. 35: Nick Drake - "From The Morning" If you're a fan of Nick Drake, you'll know all about his "Drone Note". If you don't the "Drone Note" is a note Nick Drake would play repeatedly not as a bass line as an additional sound. Sometimes I've found the most powerful part of a song is not always a solo or verse, but the subtle changes most people miss. This is a perfect example, this simple flat note change sets the whole tone of the song. The prime example of this takes place around 1:06 in the song. Listen for it through the rest of the song once you've heard it 34: The Beatles - "Getting Better" Crisp, bright and to the point. When this came out in 1966, this chord change would have been the greatest thing anyone heard. Its pure genius on Paul's part, the progession is simple and effective, its catchy and stays in your head. 33: The Guess Who - "American Woman" (Single Version) Like #34, this chord progression will stay in your head all day, its very catchy and gritty. This riff is so memorable that you'd be hard pressed to find someone who DIDN'T know it. 32: Doc Watson - "Shady Grove" Even if you don't like Bluegrass, you have to admit that the alternating guitar/banjo solo work on this song is smart. Essentially the "solos" are variations of what they play during the main verse and get more complex as the song progresses, providing a melodic evolution throughout the song. 31: The Beatles - "Get Back" Billy Preston's Keyboard Solo on "Get Back" sets this song in stone. There are two parts that MAKE the song Get Back, John's Lead Guitar, and Billy's Keyboard. If you've ever heard a version of Get Back without the Keyboard solo, it just sounds empty and hollow, Billy came up with a Solo that is memorable, something everyone knows filled with melodic changes, it seems to be all over the place. I've been guilty of whistling along many times. 30: Allman Brothers Band - "Blue Sky" Normally I don't like long guitar solos, but this is an exception. Starting at 1:07 the solo runs until 2:28 when a second guitar kicks in by 2:42 the solo has been handed over to the other guitar seamlessly and the solo continues until 4:15 when they make their way back to the lyrics. Essentially this song is one long guitar solo, but its smooth and pleasant to listen to, if you are in the right mood, the solo conveys the emotion in the song. 29: The Beach Boys - "California Girls" Ahh the intro to "California Girls", Again we revisit the Beach Boys and the genius of Brian Wilson. The intro has an epic sound to it, its an intro that takes you somewhere.. where? why to California! If there could be music every day when the sun rose over California, it would be this first 22 seconds of "California Girls". Use your imagination and picture LA as the sun rises with this as a background and you'll see what I mean. 28: 10,000 Maniacs - "These Are Days" The Opening 45 seconds of "These Are Days" (Unplugged version of course!) is a suprisingly interesting piece of music. First its the Mandolin, then the Guitar Joins In, Then the Bass, Organ, and Piano all before Natalie Merchant even sings, The timing of every instrument is perfect and builds the song up to a rising start. 27: Arlo Guthrie - "City Of New Orleans" Of course I had to do a railroad song, but not any old railroad song. This is the ONLY song that captures the sense of riding a train, musically. Listen to Arlo's light melodic guitar as it drives the song. The piano adding the additional "sway" and the simple drum track adding that "clickity clack" sound. While the song itself is a sad tribute to the death of the railroad, the music itself keeps the essence alive. 26: Dave Matthews Band - "Spoon" Bela Fleck's banjo work on "Spoon" is amazing. From the handsome banjo solo to the compliment to Dave's guitar Bela does a beautiful job with the song. This is no folky banjo, this sounds very much right at home with the mood of the song. What always sticks in my mind is the little "secret song" played by what sounds to be Dave Matthews, Tim Reynolds and Bela Fleck. Its a running improvision which Before These Crowded Streets was tied together with. Part of this "tune" can be heard at the very end of "The Last Stop" and shows up again in a longer haunting form with words after "Spoon". 25: The Beach Boys - "Heroes And Villains Suite" There is a bit of Orchestra at 2:06 in the unfinished track from Smiley Smile . This is NOT in the later released version of "Heroes and Villains". Smiley Smile was intended to be Brian Wilson's masterpiece, sadly Brian never finished it with the beach boys. While bootleg versions differ in how "Heroes and Villains" sounds, one includes a neat little orchestra backing written by Brian. This little bit of music captures the essence of the song, a tribute to Americana. 24: George Harrison - "I'd Have You Any Time" The Lead Guitar in "I'd Have You Anytime" is classic George. Elegant and beautiful, each note is refined and sings the emotion of the song. The guitar seems to reach out invite you into its embrace just as much as the lyrics. 23: Gordon Lightfoot - "If You Could Read My Mind" "If You Read Between The Lines You'll Know That I'm Just Tryin To Understand..". When someone leaves you, its hard to understand the reasoning why. In a song that captures that feeling beautifully, this one line stands out because its not a simile like the others. In fact its telling the person who left him for the answer, because he himself does not know. Its a powerful statement one a lot of people can associate with at one point or another. 22: Ben Folds Five - "Philosophy" The Opening Piano to "Philosophy" is An absolutely beautiful piece of music! It has always suprised me that this song wasn't more popular and not played on the radio. Everytime I hear it I wish I could play this on the piano. 21: Jewel - "Varg Och Delfin" At around 1:31 Jewel hits a high note on "Varg Och Delfin" or "Swedish Lullaby" for those who can't remember the title. Jewel has a beautiful voice, but when she hits that long high note it sends chills down my spine. This is one of the most beautiful songs Jewel sings, if you've never heard it, give it a listen, you'll be impressed. 20: Fleetwood Mac - "Rhiannon" How can you NOT love that guitar riff at the beginning. The riff itself is simple, but its hypnotic and stays with you. Ask someone about the song and chances are they will remember the riff specificly. 19: Murray Head - "One Night In Bangkok" Half Instrumental, Half Pop Song, All 80's! The Song starts out like a soundtrack and then at 1:48 it all changes and becomes an interesting pop song! Its a unique mix of good orchestrated sound and what was modern at the time. Even if you hate the song, it suprised you the first time you heard the song thats for sure. 18: Dave Matthews Band - "The Stone" When you see a musician live and they switch from one song to another seamlessly its always a treat, but when they do it on a studio album, its even better. In this case the orchestra backing Dave Matthews on "The Stone" pulls a fast one on you, one you might not have even caught until now. At the end of the song around 6:12 the orchestra starts playing "Can't Help Falling In Love" the transition is so natural with the rest of the song, that even the astute of hearing don't usually pick it out. 17: Jarvis Church - "Run For Your Life" As I pointed out before, background vocals sometimes say things you miss. In this case, you can't miss what the background vocals are saying. In a song about crazed fans, what would help drill the point home better than a rousing chorus of: "Run For Your Live" "Cuts You With A Knife" "Lying On The Sidewalk" "Heart In Your Hand". You can't get any more direct than those lyrics! 16: Santo And Johnny - "Sleepwalk" Everyone has heard this song once in their life. Not everyone knows the title or who performs it. :) Its one thing to make your guitar sing, but to make a guitar cry like this song takes some skill. If you are feeling down, and hear this song, you will want to cry! It always makes me want to cry. 15: Cake - "Love You Madly" Sometimes I hear a percussionist that makes me wish I could drum. This song is a perfect case of just that. From the opening "ticka-swish" gentle cymbal ringing to the background "shuffle" sound this is a busy percusive song. Pay attention to the drum track sometime and hear it for yourself. 14: Johnny Cash - "Hurt" Its one thing for Johnny Cash to have done a cover of a Nine Inch Nails song, but to do it with so much emotion and that you feel regret and sorrow as you listen is worthy of praise. Now to be fair, I am cheating a bit, the song is a lot more power if you watch the video for it. Just as the piano starts around 2:28 the video becomes very powerful and will wear down on even the hardest of hearts. 13: Mazzy Star - "Fade Into You" The chord progression of this song, as simple as it may be, has a habit of popping in my head everytime I feel down. Combined with the fact this song has some of the most depressing lyrics ever written, this song is pure 100% depression. The interesting part, is that the song is the same chords over, and over, and over on the guitar. If I were to ever kill myself, it would be to this song. All kidding asside, I have an odd fascination with this song. While it is depressing, it is beautiful and gets stuck in my head quite often. 12: Bobby Horton - "Long Ago" I love Civil War music, this song has a pretty melody and the introduction is no exception. While the rest of the song is about the brotherhood formed between soldiers (as told by aged soldiers), the intro perfectly captures the essence of youthful innocense of these soldiers marching to war. While the song is about the Civil War, the message is timeless. 11: Eric Claption - "Layla" If there was EVER a favorite guitar lick in my mind its the opening riff of Layla. Its instantly recognizable, full of energy and a true classic. If you hear the riff, you'll want to scream out "Layla!", I know I do. 10: Dave Matthews & Tim Reynolds - "Warehouse" (Live At Luther College) By now you should know I am a sucker for intros, this one takes the cake. Weighing in at 3:30 this intro starts simple and becomes a full blown symphony of music. Dave and Tim working together here paint a beautiful musical portrait. If you listen carefully, you can hear throughout the intro where Dave and Tim stay perfectly in sync with each other, complimenting the other. This is my all time favorite intro! 9: Fleetwood Mac - "Big Love" (Live) Off the Best of CD comes this live gem. Most importantly the solo is a testiment to the skill of Lindsay Buckingham. I am always a fan of complex picking, and this is some of the cleanest and fastest picking I've heard. 8: Dave Matthews - "Stay Or Leave" Dave is known for catchy riffs and bass runs, this song is no exception. However it has one thing going for it orchestration! 2/3rds of the way through the song the Orchestra kicks in and helps drive home the whole message of the song. As the song progresses it starts quiet and builds with more power and energy which feeds the emotional reflection of the song. This is a perfect case of a song being "completed" by an orchestra. 7: Led Zeppelin - "Bron-y-aur Stomp" Yes finally Zeppelin makes it on the list. ;) This song has one of the most creative rhythm guitar parts I've yet heard. However, this is VERY hard to hear in the song except towards the beginning. While a band today would simply used some power chords or a basic riff for the rhythm, Zeppelin goes one further by using one wicked little bass run in there. 6: Dave Matthews Band - "Halloween" Hearing a musician cuss sometimes isn't a big deal. However when you hear one cuss you usually avoids it, you KNOW he's pissed about something. However if you'd been in love and asked someone to marry you 5 times and get turned down like Dave was, you'd be resentful too. What better way to vent your anger than with a song! Around 3:02 Dave lets loose with the line "Tell us are you satisfied with fucking..." At this point his voice is a complete growl and that anger is very apparent. Something few artists can truely capture in their voice. I imagine Dave had a sore voice for a few days after he recorded this one. However, you can't get much angrier than this song! 5: The Beatles - "Dear Prudence" My idea of a perfect song is one that evolves as you listen to it, such is the case with Dear Prudence, it starts slowly, hypnoticly. However around 2:50 the song reaches a crecendo before coming to rest softly and gentle just as it started. It is during this time that you can count 6 different instruments if you've been paying attention, while the beatles couldn't have played all of them at the same time, the use of tracking here pays off beautifully and the sound generated is vibrant, exciting and alive. 4: The Beach Boys - "Surfer Girl" Everyone loves a love song, but no love song is as perfect as "Surfer Girl". If you pay attention to the lyrics its evident that Brian Wilson was a smart songwriter. Here we have honest words of admiration from one person to another. There is nothing tragic, no problems or anything stopping these two lovers. Brian paints a picture of perfection between a boy, a girl and their ocean. No where in the song does anything come between what he loves best, the ocean and his surfer girl. This song offers a view into the perfectness of true love, a view of what is important, that special someone and how much of a part of your world they are to you. 3: "Ashokan Farewell" Often associated with being a Civil War song, this song is actually ABOUT the Civil War and was written afterwards. In the right setting, this song will make even the strongest heart cry with its beauty and haunting sound. As far as waltzes go, this is the top of the top. Another case where the song evolves, starting alone and building a harmony of instruments this song reaches its peak with a full orchestra. But the most moving part of the song is the very when all other instruments cut out, leaving a single violin to carry on. 2: The Beatles - "The End" When your band is releasing its last studio album, how do you say goodbye? Well you give them something to remember! In this cause, the alternating guitar solos in "The End". Paul, George and John all take turns in that order playing solos each one showcasing their individual style from Paul's refined sound, to George's Elegance and John's raw upfront style. Each one of these solos is a beauty! but the last solo from George will send a shiver down your spine. All in all, the perfect way to say goodbye to your fans. 1: Dave Matthews And Tim Reynolds - "Typical Situation" (Live At Luther College) I know I know, What am I smoking? This song as number one? Over The Beatles, Zeppelin, Etc?? Well there is a good reason why! This song features what I consider to be the "perfect" guitar solo. Tim's handywork pays off as you listen to it, every note compliments the Dave's playing, and unlike most solos this isn't Tim's show off time, its his chance to shine melodicly with Dave. Around 5:25 Tim sounds to do the impossible, if you listen closely Tim has managed to himself and Dave to sound like 3 guitars! I absolutely LOVE this solo and when it comes on, I crank the volume on my stereo just to showcase it! Now I don't expect you to agree with me here, but those are my favorites. Tell me what favorite song parts you have in the comments section, I'd love to hear them.

Well I am all moved, it took a couple days, and I am still sore. But now I am moved into Tony and Corey's house, its a nice place. Daniel is there as well, he and I are sharing a room at the moment. Although he seems to have vanished, he wasn't home all night lastnight and wasn't there in the morning. Today at work we had an issue with Sprint and were "down" for about an hour. During this time I was unable to work on my current projects so I decided to not just sit and stare at the wall. I went back to a favorite pastime: Colorizing Photos. Yep sounds nerdy huh? Its actually quite enjoyable, and its something Taylor got me hooked on doing. Essentially I take a black and white picture I find somewhere and add color to it as realisticly as possible. Lets take a look shall we! Original Black and White: I've had this picture on my computer for a while, someone was selling it on ebay so I stole their scan. I do this quite often and yes I know I am not "supposed" to, but it makes for good reference material. One day I will build a model of this little engine, its the only EMD Model 40 I've liked. This engine still exists at Traveltown in LA. It does not however, wear this paint job. NAS stands for Naval Air Station in case you were wondering. Colorization: The first step I always take is to start doing basic color work to fill the scene in. I use about a 5px diameter (feathered) brush in Photoshop set to "overlay" at 51% opacity (sometimes less). I begin painting color over the gray tones, this helps to keep the depth in the picture. One important note, when using overlay, if you brush something and brush it again, it WILL wash out the detail and make the color brighter. Another tip, use colors darker than your desired color. Since you are using transparent colors they will turn out lighter than what you selected in the color picker. Once you get the picture colored up, take a moment and look at it, neat huh? Additional Depth: While the color looks nice, it lacks one thing, dark shadows and vibrant color. On the whole, an image will look washed out when using overlays. I work around this problem by adjusting the color/hue or the brightness and contrast. In this case I selected everything but the sky and upped the brightness to +27, the contrast to +30. But what about the sky? I rendered a light on the picture. In this case I used an omni directional light moved way up above the top of the picture, this is what gives the picture that "bright sky" look. Caveats: Now this picture isn't 100% correct colorwise, most of it is speculation on my part. The switcher I did not know the color for, I know the Navy did like to use blue on their engines (and cars) at one point. However they used a darker blue than I used. The freight cars are in "generic" colors, excepting the boxcar on the right, which I did in fact know the right color for (it is colored appropriatly). Other than these things, I am pleased with how the image came out, I could easily fool a lot of people with it on the first glance. What do you think? This

Its amazing how fast time flies. I remembered today that some of my oldest friends I have are the ones I care about the most, and ones that care about me the same. In this case, my best female friends or my "Angels". We all have friends that have influenced our lives in some way, my "Angels" are the brightest example of influence in my life. I figured I'd take a little time today to talk about them, some of my friends may have never heard me talk about them. This doesn't mean they aren't important to me, in fact they are very much so. Celeste I've known Celeste for 7 years now. I met her back in the spring of 97 through a chatroom I used to visit frequently. Her and I talked for a while and then found out that we lived very close to each other. Early on we talked on the phone a lot and one day we decided to meet in person, I made the drive down to Citrus Heights to meet someone who would change my life forever. Celeste is not only the first person I ever met from the internet but is the first true friend I had ever had. While her and I never went out because we didn't want to hurt our friendship, we've always been close. In those days I was very depressed and trying to conform to what was "cool" by the definition up here. Because of this I was never really happy. Celeste taught me that I didn't need to fit in with everyone else, that I was fine the way I was. In her eyes it was everyone else that didn't accept me as the problem. She taught me how to be a good friend and to just be honest and to not let anything stand in the way of caring for those around you. I learned that depression was simply a hole I had dug myself into, and everytime I felt bad about myself, I dug myself deeper into the hole. Through her kindness and love I became far more caring to others around me and realised that seeing others happy, was deep down one of the things that makes me happy. Celeste has always been part of my family, and the rest of her family accepted me as a part of their family, I became such a part that I was there for Celestes graduation and I have spent every Christmas with them. Sometimes its the only thing I know I can count on in the world. Those of you that know me, know I wear a silver ring on my left hand. I've worn it for the past 6 years, inside the band is engraved the name "Celeste", to always remind me of our friendship. Hope If Celeste saved me from losing myself years ago, Hope brought out a part of me I had always tried to hide. Its no secret that I am a geek, but 6 years ago I did my best to hide it. Hope and I had similar interests and I met her through Celeste. What set her apart from everyone else I knew was her sarcastic wit, a trait I currently posses thanks to her. So if I become such a smartass that you want to slap me, you can thank Hope for that. Hope also helped bring the geekiness back out of me, she was one of the first people I really met who wasn't ashamed of being a geek. I learned not to hide the rest of who I am and to just be me, and that people who accept me for who I am, would be greater friends than those who wouldn't. Hope and I did go out for a few weeks but it didn't really work out. In the end things turned out better because of it. Hope has always stayed a close friend and while I lose track of her sometimes she always finds me sooner or later and we catch up. Sometimes I do miss "Hopie" very much, but I always know that she's around somewhere. Missy What can one say about someone that makes it a point to keep an eye on you? Missy and I met around 5 years ago through my friend Corey (now my roommate). Missy and I hit it off and went out for a short while, while that didn't work out, we stayed good friends. Missy and I have always had a supportive friendship to each other, if there is one person I know I can confide anything in, its Missy. Most of all, I know the advice she gives isn't going to be sweetened up, its going to be the honest, brutal truth. Though Missy lives in LA, I still see her when I can, and last year alone I made atleast 4 trips where I saw her. She's done everything from give me a place to stay, to riding around with me when I needed company. I talk to her on a nearly daily basis and give her advice just as she gives me. Most of all Missy has taught me how love someone and to be a friend and be supportive. If there is an example of a true friend in the world, Missy is that friend. Katie What can I say about Katie that I haven't said elsewhere? Its been almost 4 years since Katie and I met, yet it seems like only yesterday that she found me by accident. Katie has always being the shining star of what I've lacked in my life. She's been nothing but supportive and helped bring my love for railroads back to life. All of my devotion to railroads the past few years, the hard work at the museum and on websites, have been because of Katie, my muse. Katie and I have a bond with each other that others could never dream possible. Her and I watch over each other and guide the other through life. Katie is someone I know I can tell anything to, no matter what it is, just as she knows she can do the same with me. When one of us falls, the other gives a hand and dusts us off. Our friendship is based on love, trust and support. Sometimes we go a while without seeing each other, but we both know that we'd do anything or go anywhere for the other person. Each of these 4 people has influenced my life in many ways. So much so that its hard for me to put into words what they've done, and just how much they mean to me. While its hard to write about what makes each of them special, we all know between us how we feel. From Celestes smile, Hopes laugh, Missy's hug and Katie's eyes our love and friendship is one that needs no words to explain between us. I know that out of anyone else in the world, these 4, my "Angels" will be part of my life no matter what, until the day I die. I love them in every sense of the word. But they already know that :)

I spent some time today scouring ebay for photos and paper for my collection. I've found a few interesting items I may bid on before they end. I'm not going to list what they are just incase anyone reading this might want to try and outbid me. ;) I started work on proper lettering for North Pacific Coast railroad passenger cars on the computer. I managed to find a font that is so close its frightening. With this I'll be able to help the decal project on one of the email groups I belong to. This of course means that a couple of the models in the contest at this years Narrow Gauge National Convention will carry my handy work. To top that off, I'll be attending the show! My first ever trip to a National Convention like this. I am very very excited. I wish I had a model of my own to enter in the contest, but sadly nothing I've done lately is of that kind of quality. In case anyone is wondering, the next page of Henry Yerington tales will be out in a couple days. I am dragging my feet I know ;) You might even get 2 pages! HAH Anyway I should get back to work... I still haven't heard from Katie.. I wonder if she'll ever come back? Seems like forever since I talked to her last, I miss her..

Its was a busy weekend, that much is for sure. Friday night after work, Corey, Lori, Justin and I teamed up to do the first Task Force Mission in City of Heroes.. 8 and a half hours later... hundreds of vile minions defeated, my exhausted body hauled off to bed and passed out. Sometime around 2:30pm I woke up.. I sort of sat at my chair in a daze and couldnt figure out what to do. After wasting the hours away watching Enterprise Reruns, Lori went to work. Corey, Justin and I went to Fry's and to take Justin home. I managed to pick up the Disney DVD I wanted with all of the WWII cartoons on it. When I got home I watched that, finding my bed eventually. Sunday I woke up around 3pm.. Tried to go see my mom not home Tried to see my Dad not home Went and saw Johnny for a bit then he had to leave. Got bored and went to Keven's... not home So I sat there until he got home, we then wound up going to Katie's (Foresthill) to hang out with her, her boy-toy and her friend Christina. After that we went down to Matticus' and watched some Invader Zim.. packed up our stuff and headed back to Auburn.. I think I got home around midnight. Certainly a long day! There, now anyone that thinks I don't do anything can chew on that! HAH Actually hanging out with a bunch of people was fun, and it took my mind off a few things that have been troubling me.. The dreams are still continuing and I don't know what to do about it.. I think I need to go for a drive and go to one of my quiet spots for a while. I know I can't go to either of my "homes" at this point. Maybe in a few weeks I can work out a trip.

IF I COULD PAINT I'd paint my mood in shades of blue Paint my soul to be with you I'd sketch your lips in shaded tones Draw your mouth to match my own I'd draw your arms around my waist And then all doubt I shall erase I'd trace a hand to wipe your tears A calming look to quell your fears A silhouette of dark and light While we hold each other tight I'd paint a sun to warm your heart Swearing that we'll never part I'd paint the stars in the evening sky Draw their light into your eyes I'd draw a striking touch of grace That shows the gentleness of your face I'd trace your hand to hold in mine A touching kiss to mark the time I'd draw the years all passing by So much to learn, so much to try I'd paint the truth, show how I feel Try to make you completely real And with a ring our lives will start In swearing that we'll never part I offer love you cannot buy Devoted love until we die From An Old Email I Found Today

Its another day at work today.. I had to divert a little attention to the Foresthill Community TV website again and it reminded me of why I dislike my job so much. My bosses have a knack for stupid ideas to make money. Lets take a look at the projects that promised to bring in MASSIVE DOLLARS! in the past 5 years I've been here. Norcalsearch Originally Norcalsearch was intended to be a search engine for Northern California. However as the idea grew it simply became more of a big online yellow pages of Northern California, offering the sale of ads and priority placement in the listings. The problem? Well nearly every online yellow/white pages out there already does this, and had done it since before I started here. Eventually the idea was bushed to the side, and finally lost in a server crash (no backup). Yachtshare Yachtshare is the project that wont die. The purpose is to create an online classifieds of sort to allow people to sell timeshares on their fancy yachts, in addition being able to buy/sell/trade yachts and other yacht gear. Its a pretty solid idea. The problem? This project is now 4 years old, and has been worked on by no less than 3 different programmers (myself included initially), in 3 different languages. After all this time, the site does absolutely nothing. Reason? Well the idea was sound, but the motiviation wasn't, my boss is obscessed with getting a yacht one day, so in theory getting this site to make money would give him the access to yacht deals, etc.. So to this day, its still an idea that gets brought up, and occasionally fooled with. FnFMail This was intended to be an online email filtering system which allowed only people you choose to be able to contact you. By locking access to all of these people, the idea was to give you a completely spam free email box. The problem? Any one that sent you a legit email, would get blocked unless they filled out an online form, which was then forwarded to you for your approval. The catch is, while it cuts down spam, it increases the rest of the time spent with email, filling out forms, etc.. In the end I figured most people would give up bothering to email anyone using the system. Gns2000.com The only money making idea thats come so far! This site is an online organizer for GlobalNet IBO's. Whats that? Well GlobalNet is an offshoot of Quixtar.. Whats Quixtar? Well Quixtar is "Amway" just with a different name now. This site has been my sole project for the past 4 years, and has not only kept me with a job, but kept the company a float. What does it do? Thats a good question, despite the fact that I wrote it, I can see NO logical reason WHY I would shell out $20 a month to use it. There are some neat things sure, but its marketed towards complete muppets. Believe me, the people that use the site, are so plain stupid I am suprised they can pick up the phone and call us. It pays the bills, so I don't complain much. Spam Guardian FnFmail came back! Sort of.. The idea behind FnFmail came back in an effort to get our internet service on par with that of other providers that offer spam filtering. The catch? Ours was to be better and more flexible and came in two versions. A standard which simply blocked keywords, and a "Plus" version which did nearly the exact same thing FnFmail was suppsed to do. Originally "Plus" was a pay service, but when a whopping 10 people signed up after nearly a year of the service being around, it was made free. AEBolts After the Gns2000 site was picked up my boss started to gain more interest in "Multi Level Marketing" *cough*Pyramid Schemes*cough*. At one point 2 of the GlobalNet "Diamonds" left and went to a new company. To assist these new diamonds, AEBolts was created. This site worked as a sort of contact book type of site which would allow you to send a message out to everyone on your list from anywhere, up to 1000 people! The problem? This site worked pretty much like a spam system, and we got many many complaints about it. Eventually it failed and the paying crowd dwindled, finally the server crashed and there was no good backup. All was lost and the site was abandoned. Swap The boss became interested in Barter systems, and decided "Hey we can start our own". The promise was to make an ebay like site for only barter. This is to be free for people to buy, but to sell and get registered you had to pay an annual fee. The problem? Its a barter system, I'm sorry but barter does not work on a national level very well. Ideally a national barter system gets rid of the whole idea of barter and simply becomes a new currency. This project is being "worked on" but I have a feeling it will die. Netproductsales Not happy with just the barter system, my boss has devised his own Multi Level Marketing system, in which you signup and have the ability to sell electronics on your own site! So basically, its Quixtar with more technical goodies rather than household products. The problem? This seems to be a bit more than this company can chew so to speak. He's talking about creating this site like it will be a piece of cake, nevermind that we have no source for these products and its really a pipe dream that will never get followed through. Foresthill Community TV Orignally this started out as simply a neat website for the local TV station. Somewhere along the lines its become a potential to make money. How? Well by selling the same site to other local TV stations giving them an outlet online. The problem? Content! Currently the site is nothing more than a HUGE flash animation showing the same powerpoint slideshow that the station runs, with a few downloadable clips. There is an advertising system that is being written to allow supporters and advertisers on the site to get banner adds around the site promoting their business. The problem? Its a community TV station, unlike a normal stations, these stations barely run anything that will interest the average person who watches TV. Personally I've recounted that the Auburn station 90% of the time is a Windows Desktop or a Blue Screen of Death with some corny music/talk radio playing. Thats quality TV there! Not to mention, a tv station run this poorly would have no way to afford a website that offers the same boring and pointless uninteresting information ONLINE. One day, maybe just maybe, someone will come up with a good idea that makes money. Rather than the typical foolish online service that is pointless and has already been done. I am sure I am fired now after this so I don't care anyway. :D

I realised today that there are a lot of things I miss now.. Since I've moved and in the past year a lot has changed, I am not the same person I was a year ago. These are some of the things I miss these days.. I miss hanging out at Jays and the fun we used to have there. Life seemed so much slower those days. I miss Zach and his weirdness, riding around just being crazy. I miss getting in the car and just going for a drive, didn't matter where, just driving. I miss working at the Auburn office, it made my work day seem shorter, and I felt more in touch with the rest of humanity. I miss the ocean, and the mountains.. I miss camping and getting away from it all for a while. I miss my friends that have gone away.. Zach, Bonnie, Keslie, Jodie.. I even miss old Kristal and Pat. I miss working at the museum, something I haven't been able to afford in a while, and I miss wandering around taking photographs afterwards. I miss places no one would expect me to miss.. I miss LA.. I miss Missy and driving around with her. I miss San Diego.. I miss Katie and her family.. I miss Celeste and Hope and I hope they are alright.. I miss so much, and all of these things gone feel like a void in my heart.. I wish just for one day, things could be back the way they were 2 years ago, to relive those days of happiness, the smiles and the love I shared with my friends and those I care about. I wish for one day again, to hold those feelings in my heart and never let them go, to remember those days of purity and how it was all so "right".

Lately Corey, Lori and I have started playing "City Of Heroes". CoH is a massive online multiplayer game, where you create a superhero, powers, costume, etc.. and fight crime! The game is too darn addicting thats for sure. So far I have one character: Henry Yerington Yep, only in my strange mind would I come up with that to use as a name. The best part is that I wrote his little origin which is creative and again, only something I could think up. So here we go! The origin of "Henry Yerington" Henry Yerington was born as Darius Toben sometime during 1857 in Kansas City, Mo. Growing up a simple life on the family farm he longed for adventure, in 1878 at the age of 21, he headed to the famed Comstock Lode to seek fame and fortune. There he landed a job working the tiny Silver Eagle mine for a man named Thomas Harrison. Harrison, obsessed with precious metals often employed questionable methods to make his mine more profitable, exposing Darius and other miners to hazardous conditions above and beyond those common of the period. During an "experiment" Harrison modified an air drill to fire small amounts of nitro-glycerine towards the hard rock in the mine. The experiment was a failure, and a distraught Harrison claimed the men working the mine were at fault. An altercation began between Darus and Harrison, during the scuffle Harrison struck Darius with a shovel, sending him backwards into the nitro-glycerine storage area. The result was disastrous, and the resulting explosion wiped out not only the mine itself, but all of his fellow miners. Thomas Harrison was believed to be the sole survivor. However the exposure to nitro-glycerine to Darius' skin triggered a long dormant mutation, allowing him to control pure energy. Freeing himself from the mine he sought revenge against Harrison, finally catching him near the town of Dayton, NV. Darius spared no mercy on Harrison whom he knocked down a ventilation shaft with his new found powers. Witnesses claimed Darius killed Harrison out of cold blood, and Darius became a wanted man. Fearing death and confused by the nature of his new found powers he fled the area. Heading East, he adopted many different guises to hide his past. Wandering from town to town lead him to experience the honesty and compassion of many strangers, he adopted the name of a kind gentleman that had once helped him in his days in the Comstock: "Henry Yerington". Under this name he has lead a lifelong crusade against villainy in the name of the hard working folk. Creative huh? ;) In addition to playing the game, I have decided that I will make a weekly comic strip based on my characters exploits in game. I may or may not run with it for more than a few weeks. I am not sure how well accepted it will be. The best part, is that while I can write the stories, I can't draw the comic myself. Rather than have someone else do it, I felt what better way to capture the feel of the game than through screenshots. Oh but thats cheesy! you say? Not quite.. Simply using a screenshot would be cheesy, this is where I am going on step further. Using advanced photoshop techniques I am going to take those screenshots and convert them to comic art. The images will be something along the lines of what would be seen in a graphic novel.
